newsitem.title: UK: CRICKET-ENGLAND'S LAST SIX WICKETS TUMBLE FOR 70.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-ENGLAND'S LAST SIX WICKETS TUMBLE FOR 70.

text.p: Australian pace pair Glenn McGrath and Paul Reiffel shared five of the wickets as England's last six tumbled for 70 in the fifth Ashes test on Saturday.
England slumped from 243 for four to 313 all out, in reply to Australia's first innings of 427, on the third day at Trent Bridge.
The touring team lost Matthew Elliott for 37 on their way to 56 for one in their second innings at tea, when they led by 170.
England, 188 for four overnight, prospered initially as Graham Thorpe and test debutant Adam Hollioake, his Surrey team mate, took their fifth wicket stand to 102.
Thorpe (53) and Hollioake (45) then both fell in the space of five balls.
Hollioake edged Reiffel and Mark Taylor took a fine catch low at first slip.
Thorpe, dropped by Steve Waugh on 31, was caught at short leg off leg-spinner Shane Warne.
Adam Hollioake did not have the opportunity to bat with his 19-year-old brother and fellow debutant Ben, who played confidently in making 28 before he also fell to Reiffel.
McGrath removed Robert Croft and Andy Caddick in quick succession and ended a last-wicket stand of 23 between Dean Headley and Devon Malcolm by bowling the latter.
McGrath finished with four for 71 and Warne ended with four for 86.
Elliott, Australia's leading run-scorer in the series, was out to a brilliant catch on the square-leg boundary by John Crawley just before tea after making his 37 from 40 balls.
Australia lead the six-test series 2-1 and need only draw here to keep the Ashes, of which they are holders.
